content: Reflected on turning 22. It's a time of rebuilding, not just my career but my life's direction. The job market is tough, but so am I.
Had coffee with an old mentor. He's introduced me to a few key players in quant trading. Networking feels like planting seeds, but the harvest could be worth it.
Spent the last few days diving into machine learning literature. Got a better grasp on reinforcement learning for market prediction. Progress feels slow but steady.
Tried to reach out to a top-tier quant firm. No response yet. It's like shouting into the void. But I've also started sketching out my own trading algorithm. Small steps forward.
Met with a former colleague for lunch. He shared some insights on risk management in trading. It's like a puzzle piece falling into place.
The personal trading algorithm is coming along. Implemented a basic risk assessment module. It's rudimentary, but it's a start.
Had an interview with a quant trading firm. They're interested but want to see my work. Sent over some initial code from my project. It's nerve-wracking but exciting.
Analyzing past trading losses has been eye-opening. Identified a few key mistakes in my strategy. It's like reviewing a battle plan to refine tactics.
Connected with another mentor. We discussed the societal implications of AI in trading. How do we ensure it benefits society and not just the elite?
The job search is a grind, but I've got a second interview lined up. It feels like progress, even if it's incremental.
Spent the last few days refining my algorithm. Added a machine learning module for market prediction. It's like tuning a piano—precision is everything.
Had a breakthrough in my trading strategy. Realized I was overcomplicating things. Simplicity might be the key to success.
Met with a group of peers to discuss ethical trading practices. The conversation was enlightening. How do algorithms balance speed and fairness in trading?
Sent an updated version of my trading algorithm to a potential employer. Waiting to hear back feels like waiting for a verdict. But I'm ready to pivot if needed.
Interview went well. They're impressed by my algorithm but want to see real-world application. It's time to put theory to the test. The journey continues, one step at a time.
